Build¶

These scripts are all part of the general process of taking the raw data and publishing it through our database. The script initialize.py essentially runs each of these in order.

Parse¶

Parsing logic for various pages for each sale.

Returns either a dict of list of dicts.

class scripts.parse.AllPurposeParser(html_path)¶

Parsing that is not specific to any table.

static get_document_id(html_path)¶

Parse HTML and return the document ID.

Parameters:html_path (str) – The file path to a property sale HTML file.
Returns:The document ID. Ex. ‘OPR123456789’
Return type:str

Returns:A string containing the field in the row. Ex. ‘SALE’

Parameters:html_path (string) – A path to a sale file. Ex. ‘/path/OPR123456789.html’

Build¶

Receive sale HTML, hands off to parse.py, which returns structured data.

This then commits the returned structured data.

class scripts.build.Build(initial_date=None, until_date=None)¶

Take structured data and enter into database.

build_all()¶

Run through all of the building methods.

commit_to_database(table, output)¶

Commit to database using nested transactions and exceptions.

dict_parse(parser_name, table)¶

Parse data structured in a dict, which is how details returns.

Parameters:
  • parsername – [description]
  • table – [description]
list_parse(parser_name, table)¶

Parse data structured as a list of dicts.

This is how locations, vendees and vendors returns.

Geocode¶

Use the Google Geocoding API to geocode addresses.

Returns ZIP codes, latitude, longitude and an accuracy rating. A rating of “ROOFTOP” or “RANGE_INTERPOLATED” is good enough for publication.

This also includes a method that uses PostGIS to find the neighborhood in which each sale occurred, working with a neighborhood shapefile available from [data.nola.gov](http://data.nola.gov).

class scripts.geocode.Geocode(initial_date=None, until_date=None)¶

Geocode class that needs no input.

geocode()¶

Update latitude, longitude, rating & zip in the locations table.

get_rows_with_null_rating()¶

Return query result for locations with rating IS NULL.

Returns:SQLAlchemy query result.
neighborhood_found()¶

Use PostGIS to find which neighborhood a long/lat pair is in.

no_neighborhood_found()¶

If no neighborhood is found, update with “None” in nbhd field.

process_google_results(result)¶

Return a dict of the returned geocoding results.

Parameters:result (JSON) – The returned results from Google.
Returns:A dict with rating, latitude, longitude and ZIP code.
Return type:dict
update_locations_with_neighborhoods()¶

Find neighborhoods and handles if none found.

Clean¶

This has two classes: Join and Clean.

Join joins each of the four sale tables (details, vendors, vendees and locations) on their document ID and commits each sale to the cleaned table.

Clean has methods to check for errors, mistakes and style issues. It utilizes libraries.py, a collection of items to check for.

class scripts.clean.Clean(initial_date=None, until_date=None)¶

Clean the joined tables and commit to cleaned.

class scripts.clean.Join(initial_date=None, until_date=None)¶

JOIN the four individual tables.

add_location_fields_temp_hack(incoming_rows)¶

The SQLAlchemy doesn’t yet support WITHIN GROUP.

This is necessary for using mode() aggregate function in PostgreSQL 9.4 (see get_locations() for normal use). So instead, this hack will temporary do that job.

Return SQL query of details table for given date range.

Return SQL query of vendees table for given date range.

Return SQL query of vendors table for given date range.

Run a JOIN on subqueries.

Publish¶

Run checks on cleaned table to make sure data is ready for publication.

Checks for things such as lat/long coordinates outside of New Orleans, sale amounts that are questionably high or low and whether the sale has a date or not.

Sales can fail for detail data (detail_publish field) or location data ( location_publish). If a sale fails meet all criteria for each field, it will be set as False. Sales will only appear in the table if detail_publish is True but location_publish is False. If both are False, then sale won’t appear at all.

class scripts.publish.Publish(initial_date=None, until_date=None)¶

Run checks for data integrity.

check_east_of_new_orleans()¶

Check if geocoded coords are within east border of New Orleans.

check_geocoder_bad_rating()¶

Check if PostGIS Geocoder rating scored higher than 3: bad.

check_geocoder_good_rating()¶

Check if PostGIS Geocoder rating scored 3 or lower: good.

check_high_amount()¶

Check if sale amount is unreasonably high (>= $20,000,000).

check_if_no_date()¶

Check if sale has a date.

check_low_amount()¶

Check if sale amount is unreasonably low (<= $0).

check_north_of_new_orleans()¶

Check if geocoded coords are within north border of New Orleans.

check_relative_date()¶

Check if sale date is >6 months prior to the recorded date.

check_south_of_new_orleans()¶

Check if geocoded coords are within south border of New Orleans.

check_west_of_new_orleans()¶

Check if geocoded coords are within west border of New Orleans.

main()¶

Run through each check method.

make_all_details_publishable()¶

Assume all sales are publishable.

Set detail_publishable = 1. Then set to 0 if questionable data found.

make_all_locations_publishable()¶

Assume all sales are publishable.

Set location_publish = 1. Then set to 0 if questionable data is found.
